security_audit.summary: This is a defensive security reference skill containing documentation and a vulnerability scanner. The Python script scans local files for security issues using pattern matching without executing any code or making network calls. All documentation promotes security best practices. No malicious patterns detected.

content.value_statement: Building secure applications requires understanding OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities. This skill provides comprehensive security patterns and an automated scanner to detect hardcoded secrets, SQL injection, XSS, and other critical vulnerabilities before deployment.
actual_capabilities: Scans TypeScript/JavaScript files for 20+ vulnerability types
Detects hardcoded secrets (API keys, passwords, tokens)
Identifies SQL injection patterns and XSS vulnerabilities
Checks for weak cryptography (MD5, SHA1) and insecure randomness
Validates JWT security, CORS configuration, and cookie settings
Provides comprehensive security documentation for all OWASP categories
limitations: Scanner only supports TypeScript and JavaScript files
Automated scans may produce false positives requiring manual review
Does not execute dynamic analysis or penetration testing
Security patterns are reference material only; implementation requires developer action

prompt_templates.title: Database security

prompt_templates.title: Full security audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Run validate-security.py on src/ directory and report all CRITICAL and HIGH severity findings with remediation guidance

output: Recommendation: Add expiresIn option to jwt.sign()
Consider fixing the TypeScript error instead of suppressing it

best_practices: Always validate and sanitize user input with Zod before processing
Use parameterized queries (Drizzle ORM) to prevent SQL injection
Store secrets in environment variables, never hardcode credentials
Implement proper authentication with secure session management
anti_patterns: Using string concatenation in SQL queries (causes SQL injection)
Storing passwords without hashing (use bcrypt with 12+ rounds)
Exposing internal error messages to users (causes information disclosure)
Allowing all origins in CORS configuration (enables cross-site attacks)

faq.question: Which file types does the scanner support?
faq.answer: The Python scanner supports .ts, .tsx, .js, and .jsx files. It excludes node_modules and .next directories automatically.

faq.question: What severity levels does the scanner report?
faq.answer: Issues are categorized as CRITICAL, HIGH, MEDIUM, or LOW. The scanner exits with error code 1 if any CRITICAL or HIGH issues are found.

faq.question: How do I integrate the scanner into CI/CD?
faq.answer: Run `python validate-security.py src/` as a build step. Add the command to your package.json scripts: "security:check": "python validate-security.py src/"

faq.question: Is my code sent anywhere during scanning?
faq.answer: No. The scanner runs entirely locally on your machine. It only reads files and outputs results to the console without any network calls.

faq.question: How do I fix false positives from the scanner?
faq.answer: Review the specific line flagged and add appropriate validation or refactor the pattern. The scanner uses pattern matching and may occasionally flag intentional code.

faq.question: How does this compare to npm audit?
faq.answer: npm audit checks dependencies for known CVEs. This scanner analyzes your code for vulnerability patterns like hardcoded secrets and injection risks. Use both tools together.
